summary: J. C. King was the Chief of the Western Hemisphere (WH) Division within the CIA. A memorandum from J.C. King, Chief of WH Division, to the Deputy Director (Plans) requesting approval for the revised Related Mission Directive for Mexico, which outlines objectives related to countering communism and maintaining friendly relations with the Mexican government. The documents suggest King was involved in overseeing and approving operations and directives related to anti-communist activities and maintaining U.S. interests in Latin America, particularly in Mexico and Cuba. His role involved managing agents, projects, and the overall strategy of the CIA in the Western Hemisphere during the Cold War era. The documents span from the late 1950s to the early 1960s, indicating his active involvement during this period.
significance: While the documents do not directly link J. C. King to the JFK assassination, his position as Chief of the WH Division places him in a significant role overseeing CIA activities in the region, including those related to Cuba and anti-Castro operations. His involvement in projects and directives concerning Cuba could be relevant to understanding the broader context of U.S.-Cuban relations and potential motivations within the CIA related to the assassination.
